author: Amanda Holpuch
text:
The home of Buffalo Bill in the 1991 film The Silence of the Lambs .— Photo: AP

The grim events which were supposed to have taken place in its dingy basement may have been fictional, but Buffalo Bill’s fictional home in Perry Township, Pennsylvania, is not exactly an easy sale.

“A landmark home ... featured in the Silence of the Lambs movie,” begins the realtor’s pitch for the 1906 home in Perry Township, Pennsylvania, which went on the market last year and saw its price dropped in December from $300,000 to $250,000.

An offer has finally been made, and it comes bound up in a unusual proposition. The anti-animal cruelty charity PETA (People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals) wants to turn the house into a museum where people can wear the skins of abused animals.

No animals will actually be harmed in the making of the “empathy museum”, where people would reflect on the experiences of animals used in the production of certain clothes as they tour the home used in the Oscar-winning thriller, starring Anthony Hopkins and Jodie Foster.

PETA said the house is a good place to highlight this message because it was home to the character Buffalo Bill, who imprisoned his human victims, slaughtered them and skinned their bodies to make a suit of flesh.

“We’re always scouting for ways to get our message out and when we saw that the house was for sale, given the topic of the movie, we just thought it would be great to turn it into an empathy museum for all animals that were killed for their skin,” said PETA spokesperson Kate Tuggle. — © Guardian Newspapers Limited, 2016
title: ‘House of horror’ as an empathy museum?
